sen.j: 吉野（よしの）とは、奈良県南部の別名。
sen.e: Yoshino is another name of the southern area of Nara Prefecture.
Yoshino is another name of the southern area of Nara Prefecture.
Yoshino is another name of the southern area of Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 吉野山から大峰山の山岳地帯をいい、狩りに適した良い野という意味である。
sen.e: It is a mountainous region from Mt. Yoshino to Mt. Omine and its name means that good field suitable for hunting.
It is a mountainous region from Mt. Yoshino to Mt. Omine and its name means that good field suitable for hunting.
It is a mountainous region from Mt. Yoshino to Mt. Omine and its name means that good field suitable for hunting.

sen.j: 吉野は口吉野と奥吉野に別れる。
sen.e: Yoshino is divided into Kuchiyoshino and Okuyoshino.
Yoshino is divided into Kuchiyoshino and Okuyoshino.
Yoshino is divided into Kuchiyoshino and Okuyoshino.

sen.j: 奥吉野は山々が連なる山岳地帯で、古くは大峰とよばれ、厳密には吉野に含まれなかった。
sen.e: Okuyoshino is a mountainous region in which mountains continue and it was called Omine in ancient time and, in strict definition, it was not included in Yoshino.
Okuyoshino is a mountainous region in which mountains continue and it was called Omine in ancient time and, in strict definition, it was not included in Yoshino.
Okuyoshino is a mountainous region in which mountains continue and it was called Omine in ancient time and, in strict definition, it was not included in Yoshino.

sen.j: 大峰の山々は熊野まで連なる。
sen.e: Mountains of Omine continues to Kumano.
Mountains of Omine continue to Kumano.
Mountains of Omine continue to Kumano.

sen.j: 大峰への道は修験者によって、熊野から開かれた。
sen.e: The road to Omine was opened from Kumano by mountain ascetics.
The road to Omine was opened from Kumano by mountain ascetics.
The road to Omine was opened from Kumano by mountain ascetics.

sen.j: 『記・紀』には応神や雄略の吉野での狩りの伝承が載せられている。
sen.e: In Kojiki (Record of Ancient Matters) and Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), traditions concerning hunting in Yoshino by Emperor Ojin and Emperor Yuryaku.
In the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), traditions concerning hunting in Yoshino by Emperor Ojin and Emperor Yuryaku.
sen.cmt: 『記・紀』→統一リストの表記に修正、クォーテーション追加、スペース消去
sen.e: In the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), traditions concerning hunting in Yoshino by Emperor Ojin and Emperor Yuryaku.

sen.j: 紀伊半島の中部に位置し、奈良盆地の南に位置する。
sen.e: In is located in the middle of Kii Peninsula and to the south of Nara Basin.
In is located in the middle of Kii Peninsula and to the south of Nara Basin.
In is located in the middle of Kii Peninsula and to the south of Nara Basin.

sen.j: 高地・盆地・山岳地帯が並存する。
sen.e: Highlands, basins and mountainous regions exist together.
Highlands, basins and mountainous regions exist together.
Highlands, basins and mountainous regions exist together.

sen.j: 口吉野は紀の川流域、奥吉野は十津川・北山川流域である。
sen.e: Kuchiyoshino is located in the basin of Kino-kawa River and Okuyoshino is located in the basins of Totsu-kawa River and Kitayama-gawa River.
Kuchiyoshino is located in the basin of Kino-kawa River and Okuyoshino is located in the basins of Totsu-kawa River and Kitayama-gawa River.
Kuchiyoshino is located in the basin of Kino-kawa River and Okuyoshino is located in the basins of Totsu-kawa River and Kitayama-gawa River.

sen.j: 吉野川は紀ノ川となって紀伊水道へと流れ下り、十津川と北山川は熊野川となって熊野灘へ注いでいる。
sen.e: Yoshino-gawa River continues to Kino-kawa River and flows into Kii Channel and Totsu-kawa River and Kumano-gawa Rivers continues to Kumano-gawa River and flow into Kumano-nada Sea.
Yoshino-gawa River continues to Kino-kawa River and flows into Kii Channel and Totsu-kawa and Kitayama-gawa Rivers continue to Kumano-gawa River and flow into Kumano-nada Sea.
sen.cmt: Totsu-kawa River and Kumano-gawa Rivers continues→Totsu-kawa and Kitayama-gawa Rivers continueに修正
sen.e: Yoshino-gawa River continues to Kino-kawa River and flows into Kii Channel and Totsu-kawa and Kitayama-gawa Rivers continue to Kumano-gawa River and flow into Kumano-nada Sea.

sen.j: 熊野地方（三重県南部から和歌山県東牟婁郡まで）と並ぶ多雨地帯であり、台風銀座でもある。
sen.e: It is a rainy region comparable to Kumano region (from the southern part of Mie Prefecture to Higashimuro County, Wakayama Prefecture) and, at the same time, a typhoon Ginza (an area where typhoons frequently pass).

It is a rainy region comparable to the Kumano region (from the southern part of Mie Prefecture to Higashimuro County, Wakayama Prefecture) and, at the same time, a typhoon Ginza (an area where typhoons frequently pass).

It is a rainy region comparable to the Kumano region (from the southern part of Mie Prefecture to Higashimuro County, Wakayama Prefecture) and, at the same time, a typhoon Ginza (an area where typhoons frequently pass).

sen.j: 吉野杉は秋田杉や木曽桧と並んで日本三大美林一つとされ、日本有数の林業地帯となっている。
sen.e: Yoshino cedar is deemed as one of the three most beautiful forests in Japan together with Akita cedar and Kiso hinoki (Japanese cypress), and forms a major forestry region in Japan.
Yoshino cedar is deemed as one of the three most beautiful forests in Japan together with Akita cedar and Kiso hinoki (Japanese cypress), and forms a major forestry region in Japan.
Yoshino cedar is deemed as one of the three most beautiful forests in Japan together with Akita cedar and Kiso hinoki (Japanese cypress), and forms a major forestry region in Japan.

sen.j: サクラの名所としても知られるが、多くは吉野の名を冠したソメイヨシノではなく、ヤマザクラの類である。
sen.e: It is famous for cherry blossoms, but most of cherry trees are not Someiyoshino (Prunus yedoensis), name of which includes Yoshino, but Prunus jamasakura and so on.
It is famous for cherry blossoms, but most of cherry trees are not Someiyoshino (Prunus yedoensis), the name of which includes Yoshino, but Prunus jamasakura and so on.
sen.cmt: name of which→the name of whichとしました。
sen.e: It is famous for cherry blossoms, but most of cherry trees are not Someiyoshino (Prunus yedoensis), the name of which includes Yoshino, but Prunus jamasakura and so on.

sen.j: 2004年には、吉野・大嶺を含む紀伊山地の霊場と参詣道が、国際連合教育科学文化機関の世界遺産に登録された。
sen.e: In 2004, sacred sites and pilgrimage routes in the Kii mountain range were registered as a World Heritage site by UNESCO.
In 2004, sacred sites and pilgrimage routes in the Kii mountain range were registered as a World Heritage site by UNESCO.
In 2004, sacred sites and pilgrimage routes in the Kii mountain range were registered as a World Heritage site by UNESCO.

sen.j: 「吉野」「吉野地方」の範囲は時代によって異なっており、時代が下ると共に奥へ奥へと拡大していった。
sen.e: The scope of "Yoshino" and "Yoshino region" changed with times and expanded to deeper and deeper as we go forward in time.
The scope of 'Yoshino' and 'Yoshino region' changed with times and expanded to deeper and deeper as we go forward in time.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: The scope of 'Yoshino' and 'Yoshino region' changed with times and expanded to deeper and deeper as we go forward in time.

sen.j: もともとの吉野は、吉野川北岸の原野を指していた。
sen.e: Originally, Yoshino meant the wildland on the north bank of Yoshino-gawa River.
Originally, Yoshino meant the wildland on the north bank of Yoshino-gawa River.
Originally, Yoshino meant the wildland on the north bank of Yoshino-gawa River.

sen.j: つまり、高取山や竜門岳の南斜面である。
sen.e: That is, it was the southern slopes of Mt. Takatori-yama and Mt. Ryumon-dake
That is, it was the southern slopes of Mt. Takatori and Mt. Ryumon-dake.
sen.cmt: Mt. Takatori-yama→Mt. Takatoriとし、ピリオド追加
sen.e: That is, it was the southern slopes of Mt. Takatori and Mt. Ryumon-dake.

sen.j: 最小では吉野山或いは吉野宮（宮滝遺跡）を指す場合もある。
sen.e: By the narrowest definition, it means Mr. Yoshino-yama and Yoshino no miya (Miyataki ruins) sometimes.
By the narrowest definition, it means Mt. Yoshino and Yoshino no miya (Miyataki ruins) sometimes.
By the narrowest definition, it means Mt. Yoshino and Yoshino no miya (Miyataki ruins) sometimes.

sen.j: 吉野が最初に史書に現れるのは、『古事記』『日本書紀』の神武東征の記事で、熊野国から大和国に入る通過地として記載されている。
sen.e: The first appearance of Yoshino in history books is the article of Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki" and it is described as the point to be passed through from Kumano Province to Yamato Province.

The first appearance of Yoshino in history books is the article of Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) in the "Kojiki" and the "Nihonshoki" and it is described as the point to be passed through from Kumano Province to Yamato Province.

The first appearance of Yoshino in history books is the article of Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) in the "Kojiki" and the "Nihonshoki" and it is described as the point to be passed through from Kumano Province to Yamato Province.

sen.j: 元より半神話の世界なので、正確な比定は困難であるが、現在の川上村 (奈良県)、或いは東吉野村などの吉野川沿いの地域が想定される。
sen.e: Needless to say, as it is a story of half-mythical world, it is difficult to identify correctly, a region along Yoshino-gawa River such as present Kawakami-mura (Nara Prefecture) or Higashiyoshino-mura is considered.

Needless to say, as it is a story of half-mythical world, it is difficult to identify correctly, a region along Yoshino-gawa River such as present Kawakami-mura (Nara Prefecture) or Higashiyoshino-mura is considered.

Needless to say, as it is a story of half-mythical world, it is difficult to identify correctly, a region along Yoshino-gawa River such as present Kawakami-mura (Nara Prefecture) or Higashiyoshino-mura is considered.

sen.j: 応神天皇の遊興の地となり、654年には離宮として吉野宮（宮滝遺跡）がおかれたとされ、大化の改新後の古人大兄皇子、または壬申の乱の直前の大海人皇子（天武天皇）及びその妻・鸕野皇女（持統天皇）の隠遁地、持統天皇の行幸の地として記されている吉野は、現在の吉野町の宮滝付近にあった離宮・吉野宮を指すものと思われる。
sen.e: Yoshino which was recorded as the place of the Emperor Ojin's pleasure, places of Yoshino no miya (Miyataki ruins) as a detached palace established in 654, a place for seclusion for Furuhito no Oe no Miko after Taika no Kaishin (Great Reformation of the Taika Era) or Oama no Miko (later, Emperor Tenmu) and his wife, Uno no Himemiko (later, Empress Jito) immediately before Jinshin Rebellion, and the destination for imperial visit of the Empress Jito is considered to mean the detached place, Yoshino no miya, which was located in the vicinity of Miyataki of present Yoshino-cho.

Yoshino which was recorded as the place of the Emperor Ojin's pleasure, places of Yoshino no miya (Miyataki ruins) as a detached palace established in 654, a place for seclusion for Furuhito no Oe no Miko after Taika no Kaishin (Great Reformation of the Taika Era) or Oama no Miko (later, Emperor Tenmu) and his wife, Uno no Himemiko (later, Empress Jito) immediately before Jinshin War, and the destination for imperial visit of the Empress Jito is considered to mean the detached place, Yoshino no miya, which was located in the vicinity of Miyataki of present Yoshino-cho.

Yoshino which was recorded as the place of the Emperor Ojin's pleasure, places of Yoshino no miya (Miyataki ruins) as a detached palace established in 654, a place for seclusion for Furuhito no Oe no Miko after Taika no Kaishin (Great Reformation of the Taika Era) or Oama no Miko (later, Emperor Tenmu) and his wife, Uno no Himemiko (later, Empress Jito) immediately before Jinshin War, and the destination for imperial visit of the Empress Jito is considered to mean the detached place, Yoshino no miya, which was located in the vicinity of Miyataki of present Yoshino-cho.

sen.j: 和銅年間以降は「芳野」と表記され、天武系王朝の故地として聖武天皇もたびたび行幸した。
sen.e: From and after Wado era, it was written as "芳野" and the Emperor Shomu often made imperial visits as a place of connection for the dynasty of Tenmu line.
From and after the Wado era (708-715), Yoshino was written as '芳野' and the Emperor Shomu often made imperial visits as a place of connection for the dynasty of Tenmu line.
sen.cmt: Wado era→the Wado eraとし西暦表記追加、it was written as "芳野"→Yoshino was written as '芳野'としました。
sen.e: From and after the Wado era (708-715), Yoshino was written as '芳野' and the Emperor Shomu often made imperial visits as a place of connection for the dynasty of Tenmu line.

sen.j: また、古代には歌枕の地でもあった。
sen.e: Also, it was a place of utamakura (a place famed in classical Japanese poetry) in ancient times.
Also, it was a place of utamakura (a place famed in classical Japanese poetry) in ancient times.
Also, it was a place of utamakura (a place famed in classical Japanese poetry) in ancient times.

sen.j: 平安時代には、役行者が開いたと伝えられる金峯山寺が建立され、吉野山は修験道の地となる。
sen.e: In Heian Period, Kinpusen-ji Temple, for which En no Gyoja (A semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the seventh century) is deemed as the founder, was established and Mr. Yoshino became the place for Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts).

In the Heian period, Kinpusen-ji Temple, for which En no Gyoja (A semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the seventh century) is deemed as the founder, was established and Mt. Yoshino became the place for Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts).
sen.cmt: In the Heian periodとし、Mr. Yoshino→Mt. Yoshinoに修正
sen.e: In the Heian period, Kinpusen-ji Temple, for which En no Gyoja (A semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the seventh century) is deemed as the founder, was established and Mt. Yoshino became the place for Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts).

tit.j: 鎌倉時代から江戸時代まで
tit.e: From Kamakura Period to Edo Period
From the Kamakura period to the Edo period
tit.cmt: the Kamakura period、the Edo periodとしました。
tit.e: From the Kamakura period to the Edo period

sen.j: 鎌倉時代後期には、後醍醐天皇の皇子である護良親王が吉野山で倒幕の兵を挙げる。
sen.e: In the late stage of Kamakura Period, Imperial Prince Morinaga, who was a prince of the Emperor Godaigo, raised an army in Mt. Yoshino to overthrow the shogunate.
In the late stage of the Kamakura period, Imperial Prince Morinaga, who was a prince of the Emperor Godaigo, raised an army in Mt. Yoshino to overthrow the shogunate.
In the late stage of the Kamakura period, Imperial Prince Morinaga, who was a prince of the Emperor Godaigo, raised an army in Mt. Yoshino to overthrow the shogunate.

sen.j: 後醍醐は幕府滅亡後に京都で建武の新政を開くが、南北朝時代 (日本)には吉野へ移り、皇居や行政機関を置いて吉野朝廷（南朝）が成立。
sen.e: After demolition of the shogunate, Godaigo carried out Kenmu Restoration in Kyoto, but he moved to Yoshino in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) and established Yoshino Imperial Court (Southern Court) by setting up a palace and administrative organs.

After demolition of the shogunate, Godaigo carried out the Kenmu Restoration in Kyoto, but he moved to Yoshino in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) and established Yoshino Imperial Court (Southern Court) by setting up a palace and administrative organs.

After demolition of the shogunate, Godaigo carried out the Kenmu Restoration in Kyoto, but he moved to Yoshino in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) and established Yoshino Imperial Court (Southern Court) by setting up a palace and administrative organs.

sen.j: 吉野町の吉野山を中心とするが、旧西吉野村には行宮としての賀名生皇居があった。
sen.e: Mt. Yoshino of Yoshino-cho was the center, but in Nishiyoshino-mura, there was An Angu (emperor's temporary abode)
Mt. Yoshino of Yoshino-cho was the center, but in the former Nishiyoshino-mura, there was the Ano Imperial residence as an angu (emperor's temporary abode).
sen.cmt: 「旧」「としての賀名生皇居」→訳漏れのため訳出、An Angu→an anguとし、ピリオド追加
sen.e: Mt. Yoshino of Yoshino-cho was the center, but in the former Nishiyoshino-mura, there was the Ano Imperial residence as an angu (emperor's temporary abode).

sen.j: 川上村にも伝承地がある。
sen.e: Traditional places exist also in Kawakami-mura.
Traditional places exist also in Kawakami-mura.
Traditional places exist also in Kawakami-mura.

sen.j: 南北朝統一後、室町時代にも後南朝勢力の活動地となった。
sen.e: After the unification of Southern and Northern Courts, it became the place of activities of the force of Gonancho (latter South Court).
After the unification of Southern and Northern Courts, it became the place of activities of the force of Gonancho (latter South Court).
After the unification of Southern and Northern Courts, it became the place of activities of the force of Gonancho (latter South Court).

sen.j: 江戸時代初期には、1614年に徳川家康の顧問を務めた天海の支配下となった。
sen.e: In the beginning of Edo Period, it belonged in 1614 to governance of Tenkai, who was a こもn of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
In the beginning of the Edo period, it belonged in 1614 to governance of Tenkai, who was an adviser of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: the Edo periodとし、"a こもｎ"→an adviserに修正
sen.e: In the beginning of the Edo period in 1614, it was in the control of Tenkai, who was an adviser of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: it belonged to governance of Tenkai→it was in the control of Tenkai
